The reality is that President Biden had to negotiate to avoid default and economic calamity.

As I prepare to vote, my commitment has and will continue to be a reliable, bipartisan, pragmatic leader who steps up in times like these.

We cannot default.

The details of this bill matter. Americans want to balance the budget by having the super wealthy pay all of their taxes. But the House Majority won't support fixing our tax system.

Spending caps that don't hurt Americans will likely be the best option for this divided Congress.

This is a terrible and reckless process. Folks are calling us panicked about their Social Security checks, whether or not they might lose their healthcare, and whether or not the economy would crash. People in Washington cannot continue to normalize this.

Now, bipartisan and pragmatic leaders in Congress must avoid default and support a budget that protects Social Security, healthcare for Americans, and benefits for veterans. 

The framework must also protect the most vulnerable Americans from the awfulness of poverty.

Defaulting on America is not an option.

It would be catastrophic: costing millions of Americans their jobs, driving up costs on all Americans, and undermining our national security.

A native of Little Chute, Sergeant Nickolas A. Mueller served in the U.S. Army. Sergeant Mueller was a veteran of three combat deployments and was killed in a helicopter crash while conducting operations in Afghanistan. He has since received 5 awards and medals for his service. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FxTX2q6XgAUDSW7.png

A native of Green Bay, Corporal William Farvour served in the U.S. Marine Corps during the Vietnam War. Corporal Farvour was killed in action while fearlessly serving, and is laid to rest in Fort Howard Memorial Park. He has since received 3 medals and awards for his service. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FxTXse0X0AQ_4hu.png

A native of New Holstein, Corporal Charles Olson and his Regiment saw some of the heaviest fighting of the Korean War. Corporal Olson was killed in action and laid to rest in Elm Grove Cemetery in Pulaski. He has since received 8 medals and awards for his service. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FxTXhFaXoAIv_Iq.png

A native of Green Bay, PFC Bernard Van Der Steen served in the U.S. Army during WWII where his unit saw heavy combat. After providing critical support to American forces he was killed in action and laid to rest in the Netherlands. He has since been awarded the Purple Heart. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FxTXUAxWYAAHxSf.png

A native of Lena, Corporal Everett Doney served in the Wisconsin National Guard and then in the U.S. Army during WWI. Doney made the ultimate sacrifice in action during WWI, and is laid to rest in Evergreen Cemetery in Oconto.

Wishing everyone a safe and reflective Memorial Day. Today, my family and I are honoring the sacrifices of those who have given everything in service of our country.
And to the fallen of Vietnam: You did not die in vain. Your death taught me and millions of others a lesson. And I promise I won‚Äôt forget it.
So to every American who won‚Äôt hear these words, to every American who perished in battle: Thank you, and may God grant you eternal rest.

One of those Vietnam vets sent me this painting. I am ashamed to admit that at first I thought it was cheesy. Now I get it. I can‚Äôt look at it without getting emotional. And I look at it every Memorial Day. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FxUeMHGWwAIg2a4.jpg

This feeling is especially acute for those who never made it home. As one veteran told me, ‚ÄúI got to live my life. Travel. Have babies. But my friends who died over there? They got nothing. Not even gratitude.‚Äù
I‚Äôve known a lot of Vietnam vets. Almost all of them feel this acute sense of betrayal. They love this country. They did what was asked of them. Why did their country act so ashamed?

Vietnam is such a complicated war. I won‚Äôt rehash the history, but we lost nearly 60,000 people in the prime of their lives. It‚Äôs an inconceivable loss. Yet the Vietnam veterans justifiably feel that their country turned its back on them‚Äîespecially those who never came home.

Today we honor those who served *and fell* in the line of duty. It is an amazing testament to our country that so many brave people through the generations have laid down their lives for our nation. Today, my mind turns toward one generation in particular: the Vietnam generation.

There are at least 5 things Congress calls ‚Äúspending.‚Äù

1. Budgets from budget committee.

2. Authorizations to spend money from various committees.

3. Appropriations from approps committee.

4. Entitlements/nondiscretionary spending by law.

5. Debt limit.

Conditioning an increase in the debt limit upon privately negotiated concessions from POTUS is one way to get things done.

But we have a chance to control spending more transparently and precisely using powerful Congressional tools such as the upcoming appropriations bills.

@TheRobertBshow There‚Äôs a provision in this debt limit deal that could strengthen GOP resolve in the upcoming appropriations process. Instead of shutting down the government in the event of an impasse, we get a 1% cut from last year‚Äôs levels, until the senate and president pass our bills.
@NGreene76 Generally, I think those folks are saying it doesn‚Äôt go far enough and we should have been able to get more concessions.
@dg001901 This debt deal arguably puts us on a better footing to do the appropriations process properly.
@BloodBrief I believe examples include: DOJ, DOL, FBI, HHS.

Conditioning an increase in the debt limit upon opaquely negotiated concessions from the President is one way to get things done.

But we can and should control spending more transparently and precisely using powerful Congressional tools such as the upcoming appropriations bills.

In order to simplify, I‚Äôve left out some details of Congressional process, and in doing so have opened myself up to valid critiques of my technical correctness, but I hope at this point to have established a framework for now conveying my message:

If you have followed my thread to this point, you now understand more about the ways in which Congress spends money than I did when I first got elected.

Unfortunately the mainstream media and my colleagues frequently conflate these different methods Congress uses to spend money.

DEBT LIMIT

When the prior statutory debt limit is reached, Congress, in order to keep spending money it doesn‚Äôt have, typically authorizes debt to be incurred for which Americans will be liable. The debt limit can be raised a certain amount or suspended for a certain time.

NON-DISCRETIONARY

These are government programs like Social Security and Medicare that are not affected by annual appropriations bills. They do not stop during a government shut down. Historically, they constitute about 3/4 of government spending, and they are rarely modified.

APPROPRIATIONS

This is where most of the action is.  

Don‚Äôt like something? Don‚Äôt fund it! Congress is supposed to pass 12 separate approps bills, but most often devolves into passing an omnibus or CR. These bills are due Oct 1, and if not passed, the government shuts down.

AUTHORIZATIONS

An example would be the Science committee authorizes $5 billion per year for 6 years to be spent at NASA. This makes it legal for Congress to spend UP TO that amount of money.

Surprisingly many government departments are not authorized, and operate on waivers.

BUDGET

It‚Äôs an aspirational guideline that typically covers 10 years. It‚Äôs reported from the House Budget committee. Years 2 thru 10 are routinely ignored. It considers discretionary and non-discretionary spending. Ironically it‚Äôs not very relevant to Congressional spending.

ROAD MAP THREAD:

There are at least 5 things Congress calls ‚Äúspending.‚Äù

1. Budgets from budget committee.

2. Authorizations to spend money from various committees.

3. Appropriations from approps committee.

4. Entitlements/nondiscretionary spending by law.

5. Debt limit.

In the past, if the rule wasn‚Äôt suspended, 3 days was illegitimately counted if text was introduced 11:59pm on day 1, sat for day 2, then voted upon in the a.m. of the 3rd day. Not so now; there will be a full three days to read it; vote is on day 4.

The Republican controlled Rules Committee, of which I am a member, will ensure that legislators and the public will have three days to read the debt limit bill before Congress votes on it. Text was made available Sunday, so the House can vote Wednesday.
